sect1.title: Working with Dates and Times
sect1.para:
Zend_Locale_Format provides several methods for working with dates and times to help convert and normalize between different formats for different locales. Use Zend_Date for manipulating dates, and working with date strings that already conform to one of the many internationally recognized standard formats, or one of the localized date formats supported by Zend_Date
. Using an existing, pre-defined format offers advantages, including the use of well-tested code, and the assurance of some degree of portability and interoperability (depending on the standard used). The examples below do not follow these recommendations, since using non-standard date formats would needlessly increase the difficulty of understanding these examples.

sect2.title: Normalizing Dates and Times
sect2.para: The getDate() method parses strings containing dates in localized formats. The results are returned in a structured array, with well-defined keys for each part of the date. In addition, the array will contain a key 'format' showing the format string used to parse the input date string. Since a localized date string may not contain all parts of a date/time, the key-value pairs are optional. For example, if only the year, month, and day is given, then all time values are supressed from the returned array, and vice-versa if only hour, minute, and second were given as input. If no date or time can be found within the given input, an exception will be thrown.

The getCorrectableDate() method adds a key 'fixed' with a whole number value indicating if the input date string required "fixing" by rearranging the day, month, or year in the input to fit the format used.
The following return values are possible, when the BCMath extension is available:

example.title: Normalizing a date
example.programlisting:
<?php require_once 'Zend/Locale.php';
$date = Zend_Locale_Format::getDate('13.04.2006', 'dd.MM.yyyy'); $dateObject = Zend_Date('13.04.2006', 'dd.MM.yyyy'); // creates a Zend_Date object for this date
print_r($date); // outputs:
Array ( [format] => dd.MM.yyyy [day] => 13 [month] => 4 [year] => 2006 )
// alternatively, some types of problems with input data can be automatically corrected $date2 = Zend_Locale_Format::getCorrectableDate('04.13.2006', 'dd.MM.yyyy');
print_r($date); // outputs:
Array ( [format] => dd.MM.yyyy [day] => 13 [month] => 4 [year] => 2006 [fixed] => 4 ) ?>

sect2.para: Since getDate() is "locale-aware", specifying the $locale is sufficient for date strings adhering to that locale's format. The method getCorrectableDate() uses simple tests to determine if the day or month is not valid, and then applies heuristics to try and correct any detected problems.

example.title: Normalizing a date by locale
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend/Locale.php';

$locale = new Zend_Locale('de_AT');
$date = Zend_Locale_Format::getDate('13.04.2006', null, $locale);

print_r ($date);
?>

sect2.para: A complete date and time is returned when the input contains both a date and time in the expected format.

example.title: Normalizing a date with time
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend/Locale.php';

$locale = new Zend_Locale('de_AT');
$date = Zend_Locale_Format::getDate('13.04.2005 22:14:55', false, $locale);

print_r ($date);
?>

sect2.para: If a specific format is desired, specify the $format argument, without giving a $locale. Only single-letter codes (H, m, s, y, M, d), and MMMM and EEEE are supported in the $format.
The format can include the following signs :

note.title: Database date format
note.para: To parse a database date value (f.e. MySql or MsSql), use Zend_Date's ISO_8601 format instead of getDate().

sect2.para: The method getCorrectableDate() uses simple tests to determine if the day or month is not valid, and then applies heuristics to try and correct any detected problems. getDate() automatically detects and corrects some kinds of problems with input, such as misplacing the year:

example.title: Automatic correction of input dates
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend/Locale.php';

$date = Zend_Locale_Format::getCorrectableDate('41.10.20', 'ddMMyy');

// instead of 41 for the day, the 41 will be returned as year value
print_r ($date);
?>

sect2.title: Testing Dates
sect2.para: Use isDate($inputString, $format, $locale) to check if a given string contains a valid date. The isDate() method uses getDate(), not getCorrectableDate() to avoid returning true when the input fails to conform to the date format. If errors are detected in the input, such as swapped values for months and days, the isCorrectableDate() method will apply heuristics to "correct" dates before determining their validity.

example.title: Date testing
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend/Locale.php';

$locale = new Zend_Locale('de_AT');
// using the default date format for 'de_AT', is this a valid date?
if (Zend_Locale_Format::isDate('13.Apr.2006', null, $locale) {
    print "date";
} else {
    print "not a date";
} 
?>

sect2.title: Normalizing a Time
sect2.para: Normally, a time will be returned with a date, if the input contains both. If the proper format is not known, but the locale relevant to the user input is known, then getTime() should be used, because it uses the default time format for the selected locale.

example.title: Normalize an unknown time
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend/Locale.php';

$locale = new Zend_Locale('de_AT');
if (Zend_Locale_Format::getTime('13:44:42', $locale) {
    print "time";
} else {
    print "not a time";
} 
?>

sect2.title: Testing Times
sect2.para: Use isTime() to check if a given string contains a proper time.

example.title: Testing a time
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend/Locale.php';

$locale = new Zend_Locale('de_AT');
if (Zend_Locale_Format::isTime('13:44:42', $locale) {
    print "time";
} else {
    print "not a time";
} 
?>
